title: 106_s2403
content: The "Targeted Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide marriage credit relief. No amendment made by section 2 will be considered a change in tax rate for tax purposes. The "Targeted Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000" provides marriage credit relief by allowing a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year on a joint return. The credit amount is determined based on a table for each taxpayer. The joint tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined based on the joint tentative taxable income, which includes earned income and certain pension or annuity income. The social security benefit of a taxpayer for a year is calculated by subtracting the sum of the standard deduction or total itemized deductions and the total exemption amount. The combined tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined by adding the taxes on the individual tentative taxable income of each spouse, as per the table in section 1(c). The individual tentative taxable income of a spouse is the excess of earned income over the total exemption amount for that year.
